name: Transcutaneous Oxygen Measurement
description: Non-invasive measurement of tissue oxygen tension at the skin surface using heated electrochemical sensors. Reflects local microcirculatory perfusion and tissue viability. Critical for wound healing prediction and amputation level selection.

physiology.principle: Heated sensor (44°C) causes local hyperemia, arterializes capillary blood
physiology.measurement: Oxygen diffuses through skin to electrode, generates current
physiology.reflects: Oxygen delivery to tissue, microcirculatory function

technique.stabilization: Wait 10-15 minutes for reading to stabilize

values_mmhg.30_to_40: Borderline, may heal with optimal wound care
values_mmhg.less_than_20: Critical ischemia, unlikely to heal without revasc

amputation_healing.less_than_30: Low probability, consider more proximal level

oxygen_challenge.purpose: Assess tissue response to increased O2 delivery
oxygen_challenge.technique: Measure baseline, then with 100% O2 inhalation

applications.wound_healing_prediction: Guide wound care intensity, referral for revasc

limitations: Affected by edema, cellulitis, skin thickness

comparison_with_abi.complementary: ABI may be normal despite poor tissue perfusion

clinical_pearls: TcPO2 >40 mmHg predicts wound healing; <20 mmHg = critical ischemia
TcPO2 measures actual TISSUE oxygenation, not just arterial pressure
Useful when ABI is non-compressible (diabetes, ESRD)
Oxygen challenge can predict response to revascularization
learning_objectives: Explain the physiologic basis of transcutaneous oxygen measurement
Interpret TcPO2 values for wound healing and amputation planning
Describe the oxygen challenge test and its clinical utility

sources.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.
